title.narrative: Institutional Support to the Ministry of Environment

description.narrative: Institutional Support to the Directorate General of Environment

title.narrative: Institutional Support to the Ministry of Environment
Institutional Support to the Ministry of Environment
Institutional Support to the Ministry of Environment
Institutional Support to the Ministry of Environment

description.narrative: Institutional support provided to the Ministry of Environment for planning and programming.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

-The Ministry of Environment has a clear planning and programming agenda for sustainable environmental development including resource mobilization and updating environmental. -Technical needs of the Ministry of Environment are assessed and met.

comment.narrative: Enabling environment for sustainable environmental development remains limited

"-Effective support provided to the Ministry of Environment for proper planning and programming for sustainable environmental development, mainly through following up on resource mobilization, on environmental legislation adoption and application, and on on the implementation of the MoE environmental communication campaign. -Needs assessment for capacity development in environmental sustainability is undertaken mainly through the follow up on the implementation of the Qaraoun Business Plan, on the SEA for the National Water Sector Strategy, and on MoE's proposals to prepare a national masterplan for the protection of mountains, regulating the land use in coastal zones and agricultural terrains.

-Environmental protection is enforced through the issuance of the National Sustainable Development Strategy, formulation and issuance of a number of environmental laws and decrees and implementation of inspection visits. -The Ministry of Environment is strengthened through the improvement of some management systems.

description.narrative: Community Energy efficiency and renewable energy Demonstration Project for the Recovery Of Lebanon (CEDRO)

title.narrative: CEDRO 1 - Community Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Demonstration Project for the Recovery of Lebanon

description.narrative: Machrek Energy Development-Solar (MED-Solar)
Energy - power generation
-Availability of end-use renewable energy demonstration projects; -Availability of relevant technical tools for the spread of renewable energy applications.

comment.narrative: Limited application of renewable energy technologies in Lebanon
-Pilot projects are properly commissioned and project is operationally completed.

description.narrative: Develop Capacities of government of Lebanon in Disaster Risk Reduction

title.narrative: June 2013 to March 2014 Donor Progress Report
REQUEST FOR NO COST EXTENSION UNTIL END OF DECEMBER 2012
REQUEST FOR 3 YEARS EXTENSION OF THE PROJECT
PMO EXTENSION APPRVAL UNTIL END OF DECEMBER 2015
Strengthening Disaster Risk Management capacities in Lebanon

description.narrative: National capacities to address disaster preparedness strengthened
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Disaster management body able to develop policies, strategies, and planning for emergency preparedness and response. - National Disaster Management plan in place - Better emergency response and recovery - Better coordination for disaster management.

comment.narrative: • Low level of government preparedness, to prevent and mitigate different types of disasters. • Absence of disaster management body to streamline and coordinate disaster management, activities. • Lack of information sharing • Lack of national disaster management plans. • Weak coordination with donor agencies.

1. Government coordination improved at the central level through the procurement of a Mobile Operations Room 2. Hyogo Framework for action 2014 progress report submitted by the Lebanese Government 3. Recovery strategy established 4. Sectoral and local level capacities improved for several ministries and governorates in relation to disaster risk management 5. Disaster Risk awareness further raised through the implementation of several activities

title.narrative: The Lebanese Expatriate Project, Live Lebanon, phase I

description.narrative: The Lebanese Expatriate Project, Live Lebanon, Phase I

participating-org.narrative: Les Amis Du Liban a Monaco
Bank Beirut and the Arab World

title.narrative: The Lebanese Expatriate Project, Live Lebanon, phase I

description.narrative: Live Lebanon is UNDP’s initiative to engage Lebanese living worldwide and private sector in supporting development efforts in some of Lebanon’s most deprived areas, and thereby contributing to the elimination of regional disparities.

participating-org.narrative: Les Amis Du Liban a Monaco
Bank Beirut and the Arab World

description.narrative: independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

provider-org.narrative: Les Amis Du Liban a Monaco
Les Amis Du Liban a Monaco
Bank Beirut and the Arab World
Bank Beirut and the Arab World

description.narrative: -Total funds donated to implement development projects - Number of projects supported and implemented through the donations -Number of Lebanese expatriate organizations and individuals signed up as ‘friends of Live Lebanon’ on the website or on the Facebook Group - Number of visits to the website -Number of workshops/events arranged worldwide under the name of or in association with Live Lebanon -number of volunteers involved with the promotion of LIVE LEBANON

comment.narrative: -No nationwide, formal, neutral and apolitical structure/channel for Lebanese Diaspora to be engaged in the support of local communities in the most deprived areas of the country -Remittances are mainly given as private donations to individuals -No online system to channel remittances collectively for developmental purposes
At least 15 community based projects are implemented At least 3 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

description.narrative: LRF Monitoring & Evaluation
The M&E unit was established to enhance the efficiency, prevent unnecessary expenditures and avoid project delays
independent political entity
STrengthened existing LRF monitoring mechanism by improving the timeliness, cost efficiency and reliability of the current LRF project activities.

comment.narrative: Before the establishment of the M&E unit, the LRF monitoring mechanism were being carried out by PAG representatives

• Monitoring projects progress and coordination with implementing agencies, GoL counterparts and MPTF Office. • Review and follow up on project reporting and submissions to the LRF. • Advisory support to the LRF PAG and Steering Committee • Support resource mobilization for the LRF

• Activities completed as per the projects’ set up work plans • Arising Challenges assessed and addressed • Reports uploaded to the MPTF website (http://mptf.undp.org/factsheet/fund/LRF00 ) • LRF PAG and Steering Committee provided with timely and adequate support and kept informed of progress and challenges faced in implementation • USD 1 million channeled through the LRF in 2015

title.narrative: Technical Support to the Ministry of Education

description.narrative: Technical Support to the Ministry of Education and Higher Education for the Implementation of the Education Development Plan

title.narrative: Technical Support to the Ministry of Education

description.narrative: Technical Support to the Ministry of Education and Higher Education
capital of a political entity

Listing of programs/activities for which technical assistance/coordination in institutional development was provided Listing of organizational procedures and related laws and decrees reviewed Number of capacity building activities designed and/or implemented 4. Increase of EMIS’ systems and applications use for information-based decision making, both at MEHE and at the school-level Listing of infrastructure expanded, innovated, and at which units Number of processes automated and used per directorate Number of MEHE units and public schools having adopted programs/projects/initiatives of ICT in Education and/or Number of students impacted by these Programs’ framework are developed and followed up on Listing of monitoring and evaluation processes integrated within the institutional operations development Monitoring and Evaluation data is being used for sector policy and planning Listing of technical assistance provided for the ESDP monitoring and evaluation related activities including operation and procedures manuals

comment.narrative: Education Sector Development Plan approved MIS system is being implemented Education Development Plan approved

1. The automation of the administration processes centrally at MEHE, in the regional offices, and in public schools is supported. 2. The Information, Communication, and Telecommunication (ICT) in Education initiatives is supported. 3. The delivery of required data outputs from the EMIS is supported. 4. Technical assistance for the ESDP monitoring and evaluation related activities is supported. 5. The formulation of operation and procedures manuals for monitoring and evaluation is supported.

1. School connectivity: 20% of target met; planning to reach 60% by end of 2016. 2. The EMIS application for schools and MEHE's administration automation has been finalized; will be deployed in 2016. 3. 30% of departments have gone through institutional reform and implemented the development plan. 4. 70% of private school's automation completed.

- Finalize evaluation of the 2010-2016 phase, and extract lessons learned and recommendations - Finalize all pending results from the previous phase, including reaching the at least 60% objective of schools connectivity - Achieve at least 85% of schools' automation - Develop priorities and new directions for 2016 and beyond

description.narrative: Integrated Solid Waste Management of Baalbek Caza

title.narrative: 00060665_00076489 Solid Waste Baalbeck PD and AWP

description.narrative: Integrated Solid Waste Management of Baalbek Caza
seat of a first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Strategy for solid waste management in Baalback adopted

comment.narrative: Absence of integrated solid waste management in Caza of Baalbek

As per Master plan recommendations, 1) the secondary collection system equipments along with the COSV co-generator for the proper implementation of the biogas plant are procured, and 2) Baalbeck maintenance workshop is rehabilitated.

-The procurement process of the secondary collection system and co-generator is completed; commissioning will be completed in Q1 2016; -Assessment for the rehabilitation of the Baalbek workshop is completed, implementation will start in Q1 2016.

- The Municipality of Baalbek is adequately equipped to manage solid waste: maintenance workshop is rehabilitated; the secondary collection system is upgraded through acquiring and refurbishing a number of trucks and other solid waste fleet; the bio-energy co-generators are procured for the successful operation of the biogas production plant; -The Kayal dumpsite is cleaned and temporarily closed as a first step towards its full rehabilitation.

title.narrative: Support to the Economic and Social Fund for Development

description.narrative: Economic and Social Fund for Development supported in enhancing employment opportunities and conducting community development activities.
Economic and Social Fund for Development supported in enhancing employment opportunities and conducting community development activities.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Number of SMEs financed - Number of new jobs created in under-served regions - Number of SMEs received business support for financial inclusion - Number of individuals benefited from project interventions - Number of community development projects implemented

comment.narrative: - SMEs have limited access to credits in under-served regions of Lebanon - SMEs have limited access to business support in under-served regions of Lebanon - Local development initiatives scattered and implemented with limited impact
Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

title.narrative: Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of IDAL

description.narrative: Sustaining and Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of the investment Development Authority of Lebanon
Sustaining and Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of IDAL , the Investment Development Authority of Lebanon
independent political entity

• Investment promotion strategy developed • KPIs for monitoring implementation of investment promotion strategy & communication strategy set • Modus operandi of foreign investors advisory committee developed • Policy proposal on IDAL’s role in economic zones developed • Action plan on investors satisfaction with investment climate developed • Export Plus policy proposal developed • Communication strategy developed • 3-year strategic plan developed • Annual action plans developed • MoUs signed • Database of economic, commercial & legal indicators developed and updated • SWOT of economic sectors developed • Public-private committees held and sector recommendations developed • Database of investment opportunities developed • New website structure developed • Plan for targeting expatriates developed and database of target investors developed • Promotional materials developed • Applications for evaluating project proposals developed • Investors toolkit developed • MoUs with ministries signed • Aftercare program developed • Survey questionnaire developed and commissioned to external entities

comment.narrative: Lack of a clear investment promotion strategy for Lebanon and capacities to implement such a strategy. Limited capacities to conduct monitoring & evaluation functions. Limited data on investment related indicators and knowledge sharing tools.

1. Develop a program to support the media sector 2. At least 60% of the strategies to promote export of agricultural goods implemented 3. IDAL's outreach to new and existing investors increased by at least 50% 4. Implement at least one initiative related to attracting diaspora investments to Lebanon

1. Support provided to the media sector resulting in development of knowledge tools incl. a white paper to identify means to finance the movie industry, capacity development of key stakeholders, and the signature of an MOU with Fondation Liban Cinema to encourage investments in the media sector 2. The 60% target reached through the introduction of a new program to mitigate the Syrian crisis impact on Lebanese exports 3. Outreach to more than 50% of new investors through investor targeting conferences, aggressive media campaign (increase of 70% of social media community), and sector specific fact sheets 4. Partnership developed with the MIEUX program (EU initiative) facilitated by a mapping exercise resulting in the development of a strategy

- Implement social media campaign to promote Lebanon and assess impact - Launch at least 3 partnership agreements to implement FDI computation by sector - Develop and distribute at least 12 newsletters (by batches of 4) targeting Lebanese expats, the Agri+ program, and the media sector/film industry - Finalize the diaspora investment strategy - Design the directory for at least 2 investment sectors - Increase annual publication base of at least 40% (incl. 2015 annual report, forecasting report for 2016, sectoral fact sheets - at least 1 new, ...) - Develop market studies of at least 2 agricultural products

title.narrative: Institutional Assistance for Economic Policy and Trade,

description.narrative: Support to the Ministry of Economy and Trade , phase III

title.narrative: Institutional Assistance for Economic Policy and Trade,

description.narrative: Institutional Assistance for Economic Policy and Trade - Phase II (MOET)
independent political entity

-- Economic growth strategy developed - Economic forecast models developed - Stakeholders coordination implemented - Sectoral studies and newsletters published and disseminated - Sectoral policies developed - Number of legislations drafted, amended and submitted to the Council of Ministers - Number of reformed procedures introduced in the Ministry - IT needs assessed and strategy developed and implemented - Support to SMEs provided and capacities enhanced - Transfer of technical and human resources to administration achieved

comment.narrative: -There is a need to develop and implement well-founded trade and economic policies, and to improve the business environment as well as to strengthen the commercial legal framework aimed at encouraging investment -Despite support provided in the first phase of the project, the capacities of the Ministry’s IT structure, SMEs support, trade activities, and implementation of high impact projects, are limited and still need improvements until full functional integration to the administration.

1. Prospective trade agreements negotiations evaluated and supported ( WTO, AGADIR, MERCOSUR, ...) 2. Sectoral studies , especially in services sectors developed 3. Support SMEs development in Lebanon 4. Legal amendment and additions introduced (ongoing) 5. MoET e-services supported

1. Established a WTO Reference Center for Lebanon at the MOET. Provided legal evaluations and suggested legal decrees and bi/multilateral agreements in the framework of the GAFTA and WTO. Launched the MERCOSUR Lebanon Free Trade agreement consultations. 2. Developed a study on the Technology and Innovation Ecosystem in Lebanon. Reviewed KPIs for SMEs in Lebanon. 3. Surveying more than 700 SMEs to consolidate opportunities for entrepreneurs. 4. Approval of 7 laws by parliament (ref. Official Gazette No. 48) drafted/supported by the project on money laundering, food safety, economic cooperation agreements (China, etc), and anti-corruption. 5. Automated a number of e-services in the intellectual property and consumer protection departments.

- Advice and technical knowledge on public finance and economic strategy and policies developed and provided - Research and analysis provided to monitor and assess sectoral economic developments and relevant studies published - The statistical data base on the service sectors developed and competitiveness studies conducted - At least 3 Impact assessment studies regarding the existing and potential trade agreements commissioned - At least 4 Partnerships agreements with international organizations and stakeholders in other ministries developed - At least 2 Training and capacity building workshops for the public and private sectors to raise awareness on international trade trends and developments organized - An export strategy developed and mechanisms for its implementation introduced - Relevant legislation drafted, amended, and modernized (based on identified priorities) - At least 2 to 3 Strategic high impact quick-wins and special projects in line with the MoET’s priorities and needs identified and implemented - Technical support and capacity building activities provided to the SMEs - SME relevant informational pamphlets and newsletters published; including the development of the SME section on MOET’s website - The IT unit partially integrated into MoET organizational structure with developed capacities - Current computerized processes upgraded into a common platform and manual processes reviewed (requirement analysis, re-engineering & development of priority processes), with at least 2 new programs designed and managed;

title.narrative: Technical Support to the Lebanese Parliament ,phase III

description.narrative: Technical Support to the Lebanese Parliament ,phase II
Technical Support to the Lebanese Parliament
independent political entity
Elections - elections

- Internship program established - Training provided to Parliamentary Administration employees - Support provided to Parliament to address reform issues with key stakeholders/participatory approach - Inter-parliamentary agreements reached - Accountability role of parliamentarians exercised and issues raised - Information disclosed - Tracking system for legislative process developed - Media Campaign to promote Human Rights Action Plan developed - Support provided to the Human Right Parliamentary Committee - National Human Rights Action Plan finalized and adopted

comment.narrative: Need to modernize the current organizational and administrative structure of the parliament, and to develop capacities of and provide support to the administration to address critical reform issues Need for further follow-up on Parliamentary Interrogations, and enhancing the understanding of government accountability to the Parliament Need to implement and follow-up on the National Human Rights Action Plan and mainstreaming Human Rights in Parliamentary work.

1. Organizing at least 2 training sessions for CSOs on women quota with the participation of relevant committees. 2. Organizing an event on the International Human Rights Day to launch the final NHRIP 3. Enrolling at least 5 new interns through the Lebanese Parliamentary Internship Program (LPIP) 4. Partnerships developed with Parliamentary Committees

1. Co-organized a national conference on special temporary measures for women participation in elections, with CSOs, women candidates, and representatives of major political blocks (Member of Parliaments) . Participated in the sessions of the Administration and Justice Parliamentary Committee to suggest the introduction of a 30% women quota to the electoral law (as a starting point). Received commitment from a number of Members of Parliament incl. the Speaker of Parliament on the adoption of the quota. Published a Q&A guide on the women quota and a study on the role of women in political parties. 2. Launched (in partnership with the Arab NGO Network for Development) the 2015 Universal Periodic Review on Human Rights report. Awareness was raised among CSOs, Members of Parliament, and experts, with recommendations and mechanisms to implement the recommendations. A task force was accordingly established. 3. 9 new interns joined the LPIP and worked with committees, directorates, and parliamentary administration. 4. Active partnerships in the form of support (logistical and advisory) provided to the Administration and Justice, Human Rights, Youth, and Woman and Child Parliamentary Committees.

- At least 3 research studies (focusing on national priority areas) published and disseminated - Increasing the number of enrolled interns to accept at least 10 students - Organizing at least one public hearing session on regional development related to Syrian refugees - Mobilize resources to develop and realize the National Human Rights Implementation Plan

title.narrative: Preparation to theThird National Communication to UNFCCC

description.narrative: Enabling Activities for the Preparation of Lebanon’s Third National Communication (TNC) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

title.narrative: Preparation to theThird National Communication to UNFCCC

description.narrative: PIMS 4611: Lebanon’s Self-assessment for the preparation of the Third National Communication to the UNFCCC
independent political entity
Submission and approval of Lebanon's Third National Communication to the UNFCCC

comment.narrative: Lebanon's National Communication to the UNFCCC outdated
-Vulnerability and adaptation assessment completed -GHG inventory and mitigation analysis on Energy, Transportation, and Industry is concluded. -Collected information is validated

-The procurement of services of an Economist to complete the vulnerability and Assessment (V&A) chapter is completed, and his first mission including 2 workshops for stakeholder consultation were organised; The first V&A draft report submitted and reviewed. -The procurement of services of a national backstopper for V&A is also completed; and his first report is submitted and reviewed. -The energy and industrial survey is finalised, as well as the energy mitigation analysis report. -Follow up on the organization of Climate Vulnerability Fund, attendend the forum in Geneva and the global consultations in Bonn. -Followed up on 2 ClimaSouth trainings attended by LARI and LMS in Italy; ClimaSouth posters are being customized for Lebanon. -Initiated the cooperation with the internatinal #climateiswater campaign: video being prepared on rainwater harvesting pilot project. -The Project was granted a no-cost extension until end 2016.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance for Fiscal Management and Reform

description.narrative: Technical Assistance for Fiscal Management and Reform
Technical Assistance for Fiscal Management and Reform
independent political entity

Improvement in key fiscal indicators Reports (statistics) on public services, social programs and subsides, and beneficiaries published MTEF updates completed Deviation of publications calendar controlled client/user satisfaction and action (survey) provided The publication of the debt management strategy The extent of deviation from the financing target FX and LL bond issuance successfully undertaken Number of tax conventions and investment agreements signed and results Proportion of legal reviews and advisory notes accepted/acted upon Report on reform implementation TA implementation ratio against plan TA evaluation and beneficiaries survey Budget support disbursed Grants and loans mobilized as forecasted Sector financing plans approved Aid effectiveness measures adopted Higher compliance rate Improved services Increased revenues collection Reduction in clearance time Reduction on clearance cost Stabilization of effective tariff rate Increase in voluntary compliance Inter-governmental collaboration Compliance with international obligations

comment.narrative: The fiscal situation at the end of 2010 shows gaps in the macro-fiscal policy measures, gauged by the main fiscal indicators and by public services, social programs, subsidies, and beneficiaries as in 2010. The 2010 MTEF. The publications programme as achieved in 2010. 2010 Medium-term debt management strategy (internal dissemination). The 2010 Financing plan. The results of the 64 tax agreements and 49 investment agreements reached in 2010 and on the legal reviews and advisory notes completed in 2010. Building on the reform programmes implemented in the previous years and responding to the gaps that remain to be filled: The Paris III MoF reform programme implementation as of end 2010. TA data base and neeeds as of end 2010. Annual aid mobilization forecast as achieved end 2010. Project-based financing situation as of end 2010. Progress of tax reform programme implementation as of end 2010 Weaknesses in the current facilitations and compliance as follows: Clearance of cargo: Average 5 days or above Documentation:Average 10 docs per transaction Compliant self assessment: Red lane 30 percent Satisfaction level of trade community: Medium to Low Percent added revenue due to Enforcement: Less than 2 percent Percent Non-compliant operations: Estimated 10-15 percent

1. Incentive proposals for sustainable energy submitted 2. Growth model for MoF implemented 3. Model developed to study the impact of oil discoveries on fiscal and debt 4. Second phase of transfer to administration completed 5. Thematic report series developed and reports widely disseminated 6. Sustainable energy/environment portfolio institutionalized 7. Requests for legal review and advice satisfactorily met/acted upon 8. Aid mobilization annual target achieved 9. Large Taxpayers Office merger procedures implemented 10. Performance Management System implemented 11. Operational Call Centre ensured 12. E-services business rules provided 13. Awareness and communication campaigns launched 15. New GIS solution implemented

1. Developed a medium term macro-fiscal framework for 2015 onwards. 2. Managed the highest Eurobond transaction ever accomplished amounting to 2.8 BN US Dollars. 3. Created a five-year debt model to assess financial and debt risks. 4. Provided suggestions to the amendment of the money laundering law passed by Parliament (ref. Official Gazette no. 48). 5. Introduced at least 10 new forms to facilitate tax procedures and services. Established new automated modules for the Tax administration. Launched an e-services platform to speed up processes and transactions for citizens. Established a one stop shop for 128 transactions. Call center strategy developed. 6. Modernization of the Land Registry and Cadastre administration supported by automation based on international best practices and training of all staff on new systems. Opening of new regional centers in South Lebanon to decentralize processes.

- Support provided so as annual fiscal and debt targets met - Impact of the Syrian conflict on the revenues and expenditures, including EDL and interest payments thoroughly studied, and socio-economic and fiscal policies in light of the burden imposed by the Syrian conflict reviewed and assessed - Publications calendar following transfer of regular publications to administration timely and successfully implemented - Incentive proposals for sustainable energy submitted - Investment agreements file being transferred gradually to the administration - Requests for legal review and advice satisfactorily met/acted upon - Fiscal reform programme implementation reported on - IFIs, EIB relationship managed and portfolio developed - MoF TA mobilized as planned - Large Taxpayers Office merger implemented - The administrative and operational capacity of the Tax Administration modernized (STR3 implemented) - E-services business rules provided for at least 3 procedures and awareness campaign implemented - Operations at the Free Zone is 5 percent faster and control improved by 10 percent - Operation in terms of Transit is at least 10 percent faster and the control function improved of 15% - Visas and permits delivery is 10 percent faster

Institutional Strengthening Project for the Implementation of Montreal Protocol in Lebanon (Phase VII)
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

-Efficient and timely reporting by the Government of Lebanon to the Montreal Protocol sustained and compliance is met. -National awareness and capacity building are raised and legislative framework is updated.

comment.narrative: Efficient and timely reporting by the Government of Lebanon to the Montreal Protocol

title.narrative: Support to Civil Service Reform and Management Capacity

description.narrative: Support to Civil Service Reform and Management Capacity

title.narrative: Support to Civil Service Reform and Management Capacity

description.narrative: Support to Civil Service Reform
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Office of the Minister of State for Administrative Reform (OMSAR) - Support to civil service reform and management capacity of public administration

description.narrative: Development of the public procurement, e-transaction, the basket of anticorruption, privacy and cyber security laws Training on Post audit for the COA judges Strategic plans developed at sectoral levels Institutional performance adopted at Ministries level Number of transactions streamlined Number of One-Stop Shops established Number of services delivered electronically Number of automated procedures Number of administrations involved in interoperability projects Number of administrations with back offices automated Number of trainees on change management. Number of entities adopting change management techniques. Communication strategy for OMSAR developed and adopted Number of NGOs trained Number of NGO projects of socio-economic nature implemented Number of municipality development projects implemented Number of solid waste facilities maintained

comment.narrative: Several relevant draft laws are developed Draft organizational structures developed and relevant draft laws approved by the Council of Ministers (COM) Relevant draft laws approved by COM and numerous training and awareness sessions accomplished Relevant COM decisions issued and a pilot one-stop shop in the process to be established Relevant draft laws approved by COM. Minimum infrastructure available and ICT training program conducted Change management identified as a standalone program in the administrative reform strategy and several awareness workshops conducted

1. Enactment of new law on whistle blowers protection. 2. Establishing the procurement management authority. 3. One e- Procurement module operational 4. Institutional performance indicators adopted at five Ministries. 5. Post audit techniques adopted and institutionalized at the COA. 6. HR units in four ministries established. 7. One additional one-stop shops operational 8. 20 main transactions streamlined based on international best practices. 9. 10 government services benefiting from the interoperability module. 10. 60 e-Services operational. 11. Develop a National ICT Asset Management System 12. Support to 10 development projects proposed by Municipal Unions.

1. Second phase of training on strategic planning capacities completed and more than 30 staff trained 2. KPIs developed for 4 Ministries to track institutional performance (as pilot) and assessed HR management capacities in 4 ministries 3. Absorbed judiciary automation resources 4. Simplification of construction permit procedures and transactions 5. Phase 1 of the e governance portal delivered and tested 7. AFKAR III: Contracts with first phase winners signed

- Follow-up on the ratification of public procurement regulations and conduct activities to support the execution of public contracts in compliance with international standards pertaining to fairness and efficiency. - Follow-up on the ratification of at least 4 laws and regulations that serve the execution of the e-Government program. - Support the adoption of the required legal frameworks and mechanisms which allow the condemnation of illicit enrichment and conflicts of interest. - Introduce modern structures and review mandates and roles of the control bodies and other relevant public administrations. - Adopt strategic plans by public administrations in accordance with an adopted methodology for at least 4 pilot Ministries. - Promote Institutional Performance Evaluation methodologies at the Central Inspection. - Secure formal approval to carry out internal control study in at least two pilot ministries. - Support the CAS in producing economic statistics, social statistics, Improving the Capacity of the CAS staff in coordination with all the stakeholders of the National Statistics system. - Support the development process of the Civil Service Board towards becoming a modern and effective tool for the management of human resources through the review and enactment of the laws governing its operation and through the introduction of ICT tools. - Reinforce the training function of OMSAR and continue the training activities at both the administrative and the ICT levels. - Reinforce the adoption of job descriptions and position classifications. - Support the appointment/recruitment of senior government staff based on merit standards and through an adopted transparent mechanism. - Streamline government services and simplify number of critical services with special focus on the business licenses that affect the doing business indicator for Lebanon in at least 4 Ministries. - Establishing one-stop shops (single window service) in at least 3 ministries. - Establish the

description.narrative: ART GOLD Lebanon is an integrated component of the UNDP “Social and Local Development Programme” (SLD), which, among other objectives, focuses on eradicating poverty, strengthening local capacities and supporting government policies for development.

ART GOLD Lebanon is an integrated component of the UNDP “Social and Local Development Programme” (SLD), which, among other objectives, focuses on eradicating poverty, strengthening local capacities and supporting government policies for development.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Pilot strategic plans developed in 2 regions in Lebanon - Territorial profiles used for elaboration on development plans - Training sessions on decentralization policies and strategic development - National Strategy for Beekeeping sector developed - Agreements and funding from DC European local authorities

comment.narrative: - Absence of a national and regional development strategy - Territorial Profiles developed for South, BSS, North and Bekaa - Efforts for Decentralization law endorsement are ongoing, implementation at the regional and local still on hold - Decentralized cooperation agreements with european local authorities (Spain, Belgium, Monaco and Italy) - LEDAs registered and ready to start operation - Open EC call for proposals include International organizations

description.narrative: ART GOLD South aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.

ART GOLD South aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.
seat of a second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Number of training sessions conducted on Computer Literacy-and no. of teachers targeted - Type of rehabilitation and equipment provided - Number of income generating projects implemented by youth groups sucessufully - Completion of construction of the workshop - Number of sessions and trainers attending the pottery training in Rashays el Fouhkar

comment.narrative: - Limited business development services offered to SMEs in the South - Pottery industry in Rashaya el Foukhar is becoming instinct - capacity of the LEDA founding committee members is weak and should be enhanced to manage projects, fundraise - Youth groups were established in the south, but require income generating projects to support their sustainability - limited technical trainings for teachers in publich mainly computer skills - Lack of educational aids and proper infrastructure for extra-curricular activities in public schools
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the South is enhanced

description.narrative: ART GOLD North aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.

ART GOLD North aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.
seat of a first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- No. of youth trained and engaged in paid work - No. of cultural activities initiated in Akkar region - No. of SMEs supported and No. of new jobs created - No. of farmers who increase their incomes - % increased in the honey production in Akkar. - No. of increased hectares cultivated with forage crops in Dreib Area (Akkar) - No. of additional tons of milk production per day increased in Dreib area (Akkar) - public space initiatives implemented in Tripoli - no. of strategic plans developed in North area - Pilot plan for GIS in Tripoli implemented

comment.narrative: - Limited public and greed spaces within Tripoli city - Local and regional authorities don't have strategic plans to aid them manage development challenges more effectively - Limited job opportunities for youth with no specific skills - Weak cultural activities within Akkar region, and youth inclined to delinquent behavoirs - Limited number of small and medium enterprises services - Excess use of fertilizers by farmers - Absence of business opportunities in the poor regions of the North - GIS already exists in Tripoli but not used effectively for planning purposes
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the North is enhanced

description.narrative: ART GOLD BSS aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.

ART GOLD BSS aims to achieve balanced and sustainable development through three main pillars, (i) the participatory approach ensured by the working groups, (ii) the local economic development, and (iii) the support of the Decentralized Cooperation.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Number of vulnerable youth and related families identified and involved in community development activities - Social Municipal offices set and operational - Number of social and economic studies and surveys produced - Development of relevant action plans - Number of students supported by the extra-curricular activities - Number of teachers trained on educational and extra-curricular activities - Evaluation of the 3 PHCCs based on relevant indicators (infrastructure, equipments, medical record use, disease management, outreach projects and public awareness etc.) - Local Economic Development office established and operational - Number of small enterprises supported - Number of new jobs created

comment.narrative: - Absence of a regional development strategy in BSS - Prevalence of increased number of vulnerable youths (particularly drugs and alcohol addicts) - Lack of educational technical assistance for students with special needs and with difficulties in learning foreign languages -Lack of extra-curricular activities -Absence of social worker’s support in the schools with lack of parents’ involvement in the educational program of their children. - 55% of the population has no public or private health insurance coverage - Existing dispensaries do not follow the generic Primary Health Care Services System and Approach - Absence of business opportunities in BSS
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the BSS is enhanced

description.narrative: •No of services delivered •No of participatory plans •No. of scholarships for school •No. of patients assisted •All municipalities have coordination mechanisms •Number of community committees formed. •Number of participants in the community committees. •Number of assessments completed in a participatory manner. •Number of individuals trained on dispute resolution. •Percentage of trained individuals actively solving disputes in their communities. •Number of assessments and updates undertaken. •Number of assessments provided to the government. •Number of coordination meetings held.

comment.narrative: •High unemployment amongst youth and women; •Limited job opportunities and weak private sector investment; •Loss and/or depletion of livelihood assets, and economic opportunities •Weak economic and productive infrastructures; •Limited financial services targeting poor and vulnerable people. •Limited knowledge on the available services by the local communities is contributing to the increasing tension. •Lack of services •Vulnerable population unable to access services •Lack of participatory mechanisms for service delivery •Local communities are vulnerable to external shocks due to limited skills and institutionalized mechanisms for preventing tension from exploding into conflict. •Lack of institutionalized local level mechanisms for dealing with disputes. •Lack of systematic conflict prevention and conflict resolution instruments being utilized by local leaders. •Limited skill base of key local leaders in dealing with disputes and conflicts affecting their villages.
▪ At least 50 Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans developed ▪ At least 60 host communities targeted ▪ At least 170 projects implemented across different sectors

description.narrative: Low-Emission Capacity Building Project - Lebanon Component

title.narrative: Prodoc Low Emission Capacity Building Programme

independent political entity

comment.narrative: -Mitigation measures limited to general description under the initial and second national communication; -Limited low carbon and climate change related initiatives / projects.

"-Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) process endorsed by CoM -INDCs process completed -Training, communication and incentives are undertaken; -NAMA waste and transport sectors prepared with respective MRC system is set and related process and tools are communicated and introduced to stakeholders -Support provided to other ministries preparing NAMAs

'-International and national consultants are on-board to prepare the waste and transport Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs); -A fisrt mission for international NAMA consultant is organized; The consultation workshop on transport NAMA -Provided support to the Ministry of Agriculture in the preparation of Forestry NAMA. -Rapid Assessment for Waste Sector and Waste Nama situation analysis completed. -Held discussions with the Ministry of Finance on unified MRV system and integration of GHG reporting in companies' tax reporting system; -FIT/derisking ToRs are being prepared; -Extra funding for the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) is received and budgeted; The procurement of consultancy services for the preparation of Lebanon's INDC is finalisd and awarded to Ricardo AEA ; Two INDC meetings with interministerial committee are scheduled and under preparation; and provided support to the Minister's office in Negotiations and INDC meetings New York Permanent Mission, French Climate Change Ambassador, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, etc.) -Participated in Climasouth workshop on Low Emission Development Strategies, and in in Global Workshop on Intended Nationally Determined Contributions in Berlin and UNFCCC Workshop for the Asia-Pacific and Eastern Europe regions on NAMAs in Bonn. -Participated in negotiations meetings: Cartage Dialogue in Paris and Subsidiary Bodies and ADP session in Bonn

description.narrative: Lebanese Electoral Assistance Project

title.narrative: Lebanese Electoral Assistance Project (LEAP) project evaluation

description.narrative: Lebanese Electoral Assistance Project
independent political entity
Elections - elections

Number and type of advisory roles on electoral reform Number and type of reports/manuals/videos/plans produced and/or published/broadcast Number of trainers trained Number and type of election officials trained Number of election districts using new results process. Number of citizens reached by voter information Number of users accessing on-line voter register Number of media briefings at media centre In case ballots are adopted, number of invalid ballot Number of new vote secrecy processes adopted in law. In case ballots are adopted, number of ballots produced. In case absentee voting is adopted, number of voters who participate as absentee voters Number of election districts included in data-management system Number of measures to improve accessibility adopted Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number and type of advisory role on campaign supervision Number and type of documents/reports/manuals produced Number and type of regulatory and procedural improvements in place Number of SCEC members and staff trained Number of participants in workshops/consultative meetings Number and type of official information on campaign supervision released Number of users of web content on campaign supervision Number of observers/media accredited Number of reports produced Number of stakeholder participants trained Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number of initiatives supported Number of reports produced Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number of judges/members, experts and stakeholders participating in events Number and type of advisory roles on Temporary Special Measures (TSMs) In case TSMs are adopted, number of stakeholders trained Number of women recruited as election officials Number of reports produced Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders

comment.narrative: Political debate on electoral reform on-going Limited technical capacity for advising on reform initiatives Inadequate technical framework for results process Limited technical capacity for improving results framework Need to ensure accurate and reliable results process Limited experience and capacity for official voter information No current strategy for official role on voter information and media; increasing political role for social media Limited use and awareness of online voter register Broad public knowledge of importance of elections but limited knowledge of electoral issues Emerging role and expectation for official websites and voter information on citizens’ rights Limited official resources for meeting media interest Possible political consensus on measures for vote secrecy No current capacity for ballot production and limited technical knowledge on options for counting and absentee voting No strategic capacity for training of officials in place All polling officials require updated training, especially if new electoral procedures to be adopted Limited technical capacity and resources for operational planning and data-management Limited opportunities for Persons With Disabilities (PWD) to access electoral process Debate for future reform of legislative and administrative framework for elections is likely to intensify Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance. Next elections will take place in 2016 and 2017 SCEC has no current functional capacity. SCEC members and staff will be new with limited elections experience Regulatory framework for campaign supervision identified as inadequate No strategy or capacity for stakeholder outreach in place Limited capacity for observer accreditation in place Significant interest from observer/media expected Debate for future strengthening of campaign supervision is expected to take place Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance No baseline data or coordinat

1. Improved candidate registration system 2. Improved results management system 3. Enhanced electoral dispute resolution processes 4. Outreach material provided 5. Increased awareness on Temporary Special Measures for women participation

1. CRRM software to modernize candidate registration and results management finalized, tested, and provided to the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities. System preliminary adopted by the Directorate General for Personal Status. 2. Developed partnership with the constitutional council, providing it with technical support to be able to address electoral disputes. Information capacity of the council enhanced with a website and the publication of 2 legal references (guidebook and compilation of decisions). The project received a recognition award for its contributions. 3. Capacities on elections operations strengthened through the publication of an electoral atlas for each electoral district with elections related data and improved storage capacity and management of electoral material through the establishment of an automated system. 4. Increased awareness on women participation provided with advisory support to parliamentary committees, with the provision of information and alternatives and facts, and co-organization of a national conference to discuss Temporary Special measures.

• Support the MoIM, SCEC, Constitutional and State Councils in the planning, organization and conduct of the municipal elections in its different stages. • Support the process of candidates registration for municipal elections and parliamentary bi-elections through the implementation of a modern candidate registration software (pilot) conducted in parallel with the current system. • Support in the design and conduct of trainings for the candidate registration officials at 26 'Qaem maqams'. • Technical support to the 26 'Qaem maqams' during the candidate registration period • Support in the establishment of the MoIM media center and hotline, and support for the maintenance and development of the website • Regular trainings and briefings for media and observers on municipal elections (depending on pre-elections period length) • Support the MoIM and Civil Society Organizations in the organization and conduct of cascade trainings for polling officials, accreditation unit, media and observers, hotline operators, CSO representatives, and women organizations • Technical support to the MoIM Operation Room during the electoral period. • Organization and conduct of meetings between MoIM and persons with disabilities NGOs in order to identify concrete measures to increase accessibility to the polling locations. • Conducting at least 3 full awareness campaigns (media and direct targeting) aiming at voter education, voter registration, and elections day requirements. • Conducting a national workshop on strengthening the participation of women in municipal elections as voters, candidates and polling officials. • Development of a guide for municipal elections focused on candidacy procedure (Arabic and English) aimed to to provide relevant information to women interested to run as candidates. • Ensure proper evaluation of programs and highlighting of lessons learned after the completion of the municipal elections with a focus on women participation; Post-electoral evaluation

description.narrative: The Rehabilitation of Saida Dumpsite
The Rehabilitation of Saida Dumpsite
seat of a first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Saida dumpsite totally rehabilitated and environmental impacts mitigated.

comment.narrative: Current dumpsite presents high risk and environmental hazard, and absence of baseline data

-The rehabilitated dumpsite is converted into two sections: 1) a Public Park (area 33,500 sqm) including 10,452 trees and plants and irrigation system open to citizens; and b) a sanitary engineered landfill becomes a green hill 65,000 sqm. All infrastructure (fences, access road, drainage, guard house/equipped room) is completed; gas and leachate are monitored.

-Trainings for the Project Team & Local Stakeholders to Ensure Proper Project Performance are undertaken; -The dumpsite is converted into: 1) a Public Park (area 33,500 sqm) including 10,452 trees and plants and irrigation system open to citizens; and b) an engineered sanitary landfill becomes a green hill 65,000 sqm. All infrastructure (fences, access road, drainage, guard house/equipped room) is completed; gas and leachate are monitored.

description.narrative: Enhacing Capacity for Social Development
Enhacing Capacity for Social Development
independent political entity

- Number of NSDS launched and adopted by MoSA - Elaboration and adaptation of National Social Development Plan - Issuance of a contractual modality with clear standards between MoSA and NGOs. - Number of NGOs classified according to an accreditation system - Number of welfare institutions classified according to an accreditation system. - Percentage of low qualified contacted NGO’s & welfare institutions trained. - Percentage of MoSA staff trained. - Establishment of an active & solid networking between MOSA, NGOs and other donors.

comment.narrative: - Lack of a national social development strategy to be adopted by ministers, NGOs, local authorities for implementing local initiatives and promoting sustainable development. - Lack of training tools and techniques to build the capacities of MoSA staff. - Absence of clear standards for selecting qualified NGOs for contractual cooperation with MoSA. - Lack of a solid networking mechanism to formulate the cooperation between MoSA and NGOs, among NGOs themselves and between NGOs and other donors. - Lack of a coherant platform among MoSA, NGOs and other donors for sharing data and and information available on services and beneficiaries in an attempt to avoid duplication and to ensure a sound allocation of resources.
The National Social Development Strategy is launched and adopted by MoSA An action plan is elaborated New criteria & contractual procedure are established

activity-description.narrative: Clearance Operations in addition to MVA and MRE operations

comment.narrative:
1.Lebanon Mine Action Center Strategy 2011-2020
2.1.Baseline is insufficient for effective planning for MRE and VA; capacity of MRE and VA committees does not allow for effective planning, monitoring and evaluation 2.2.Socio economic needs of survivors/victims are not fully addressed; prosthesis needs of survivors insufficiently covered 2.3.Convention on the Rights of People with Disability signed but not ratified.
3.1.The Lebanon Mine Action Strategy 2010-2020 is not fully funded to meet the 2020 deadline for completion 3.2.66% of land released 3.3.Women are under-represented among mine action organization staff 3.4.Socio economic value of land to be released exists but is not measured
4.1.Entry into force of the Convention on Cluster Munitions in May 2011. 4.2.Lebanon has demonstrated leadership in advocating internally and externally the CCM process, assumed presidency of the CCM in 2011/12; 4.3.Lebanon has not signed/ratified but implements mine action “in the spirit” of the Ottawa Convention

- Skills of Mine Action Officers and staff enhanced to better implement the national mine action strategy strategy - Process to adopt the revised National Mine Action Standards initiated and updating of the Standard Operating Procedures accordingly initiated - Consolidated socio-economic report to measure the impact of clearance activities of the impacted communities’ development issued - Most critical gaps in Minefield clearance and Battle area clearance capacity (teams) addresses in the North and south of Lebanon - Communication further improved with all stakeholders - Strategy for the opening of the Regional School for Humanitarian De-mining achieved - National Mine Action Standards updated in accordance with the latest version of the International Mine Action Standards and translated to Arabic - Continuous monitoring of mine and cluster munitions clearance operations ensured

description.narrative: Support Office for Consensus building, Civil Peace, and Constitutional Strengthening, phase II
Support office for consensus b
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Support to national dialogue structures, mechanisms and committees

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Non formal dialogue and consensus building sessions held and maintained Reconciliation, and legislative processes facilitated and resourced. All-party Expert and Dialogue Groups established At least 300 dialogue sessions of the all-party Expert and Dialogue Groups conducted and supported by the Common Space (at least 300 dialogue sessions during the 5 years) Number of joint publications reflecting areas of consensus within the all-party Expert and Dialogue Groups Dialogue sessions and consultations are regularly held and maintained at least once a month Reconciliation, and legislative processes facilitated and resourced Practice to Theory learning workshops organized Case studies produced for comparative learning Peer-to-peer exchanges organized Annual conference organized

comment.narrative: Building on the achievements of the previous phase, there is a need to provide further technical support to national dialogues, policy making bodies, and consensus building mechanisms provided Need to strengthen capacities of stakeholders on sustainable peace, and to draw on legacy of consensus building and Lebanese culture of dialogue, and national assets There is a lack of initiatives that build long-term confidence, interdependence and trust at the national and community levels There is a need to provide and share facilitation support and deadlock breaking mechanisms; joint learning experiences, in Lebanon and the region

1. Maintenance of dialogue sessions 2. Maintenance of shared knowledge resources 3. Maintenance of inclusive knowledge-sharing environment 4. Capacities and resources developed 5. Procedures and operations rendered more

1. More than 60 dialogue sessions held in various thematic areas 2. Finalization and dissemination of the Strategies of Response to the Syrian Refugee Crisis in Lebanon. 3. Facilitating regional peer to peer exchange on Judiciary Reform 4.Published online Lebguide Platform to support dialogue processes in informed way 5. Mapped all legal interventions on Lebanese Palestinian Dialogue

- Holding at least 75 dialogue sessions - Development of at least 5 knowledge tools - Developing new dialogue tools to address impacts of the Syrian crisis - Organize the "Practice to Theory Conference" to favor peer to peer exchange - Maintain and further develop knowledge-sharing platforms, to reach out to at least 20% of additional users - Commission at least 5 case studies and research papers on comparative learning and experiences, in Lebanon and the region

comment.narrative: -0 reduction of CO2 emissions -Regulations for feed-in tariffs and net metering under consideration -No adequate market monitoring and quality control mechanisms in place

-Implementation of at least 1.75 MW of decentralized renewable energy projects is initiated with the support of a technical firm; -A number of studies is completed in partnership with other projects and published (Renewable Energy Interconnection Grid Code; Derisking Renewable Energy Investment Study; Net-metering Study) -A number of capacity building workshops are conducted (Earthing and Lightning Protection of PV Systems, Embedding of PV technologies in building design and construction, Net-metering) and related guidelines are issued; -PV Survey is undertaken and Market Monitoring Reporting is established; -Quality Control of PV Installations is introduced in vocational schools through updating the curriculum and personnel training.

description.narrative: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions by the removal of barriers to widespread application of decentralized renewable energy based power generation.

comment.narrative: Direct: 35,500 tonnes of CO2eq over the 20-year default lifetime of the investments made during project implementation.

description.narrative: An enforced supportive policy and regulatory environment for attracting investments for privately owned, grid-connected power generation by RE sources

comment.narrative: Regulations for feed-in tariffs and net metering under consideration

Net metering effectively implemented and complemented with other required regulations and/or guidance, including updated technical guidelines for grid connection as well as adopted standards and procedures for performance testing and quality control.
Mechanism and guidelines for the implementation of feed-in-tariffs developed.

Net-metering program launched but currently postponed as it is facing technical difficulties.
Feed-in-Tariff program under consideration.
Renewable energy grid code study being launched.

description.narrative: Monitoring and quality control for RE-based decentralized power generation established and operational

Verified customer satisfaction with the RE technologies in use

comment.narrative: No adequate market monitoring and quality control mechanisms in place

Availability of annual market data for new sales, total installed capacity and net production of all main RE applications sold in Lebanon by March/April each year.
Over 70% customers satisfaction on the RE installations made

No adequate market monitoring. DREG is working on the development of a market monitoring scheme.
Quality control mechanisms being developed with responsible national agencies (LIBNOR and IRI).

description.narrative: Living conditions and trust in Palestinian and Lebanese surrounding communities improved

participating-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Palestian Refugees living in 42 Palestinian Gatherings all over Lebanon

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

provider-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: -1. Number of Infrastructure and BUS interventions executed in gatherings -2. Number of hygiene awareness raising campaigns carried out in Palestinian gatherings -3. Local authorities and local committees in the gathering supported to set-up collaborative mechanisms for improved service delivery -4. Number of municipalities engaged for improving living conditions in Palestinian gatherings -5. Number of refugee households benefitting from shelter rehabilitation and internal works -6. Number of MOUs signed between Municipalities and Popular Committees -7. Number of Hygiene kits distributed -8. National Observatory for Palestinian Gatherings in Lebanon supported for data generation / dissemination and planning tool -9. Indicators for monitoring living conditions in Palestinian gatherings developed and updated -10. A structure to host and disseminate geographic database of Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon is set-up -11. National actors and organizations active in the gatherings use data to plan and coordinate their interventions

comment.narrative: •Number of dwellers in the Gatherings has risen 47%, in the last assessment conducted by Habitat and UNDP, as a result of the Syrian crisis. •Inadequate access to basic urban services for some 75,000 original dwellers in Palestinian gatherings. •Increased pressure on basic urban services and infrastructure networks in the gatherings by 35,000 newly arrived Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria • Lack of institutions / agencies responsible for the provision of basic urban services in the gatherings •Limited Municipal engagement to improve living environment and infrastructure networks in Palestinian gatherings • Limited capacities, resources and know-how of local actors and authorities to respond to the issues in the Palestinian gatherings. • Lack of communication and collaboration among local authorities and representatives of local communities in the gatherings for addressing local challenges • Additional 35,000 Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria are accommodated in Palestinian gatherings • Large numbers of displaced families were housed in temporary structures or units that are not equipped for accommodation • Shelter units housing Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria in the gatherings are inadequate • Large numbers of shelters housing Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria in the gatherings are not properly connected to infrastructure networks (water, sewage, electricity) • Lack of financial resources of host communities and refugees from Syria to improve environmental conditions of shelters • Lack of national-wide data for monitoring living conditions in Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon • Lack of accurate information on numbers and situation of arrived Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria to the gatherings • Lack of responsive strategy for improving living conditions in Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon based on accurate data and information • Need for enhanced coordination among key national actors and organizations

-1. 74 -2. 42 -3. Local authorities and committees further assisted -4. 5 -5. 2000 -6. 2 -7. 16350 -8. Observatory completed -9. Indicators revised -10. Structure setup -11. Additional data on gatherings generated

description.narrative: Increased supply/storage of water to host communities in Wadi Khaled

comment.narrative: Limited supply and storage capacity available resulting in non-continuous supply of water
The construction of transmission and distribution water networks for Hnaider, Qarha & Knaise villages in Wadi Khaled, North Lebanon is 80 percent completed.

The network designs were cleared by the national authority in this regard which is the North Lebanese Water Establishment. 80 percent of the works is completed in close coordination with the hosting municipalities to ensure sustainability of the action.

description.narrative: 1) Number of educators teaching Lebanese and Syrian students trained 2) Number of newsletters produced 3) Number of Peace building News Supplements published 4) Number of initiatives implemented to support collective memory through non-formal education channels. 5) Number of schools adopting the violence free schools principles 6) Number of history teachers trained on teaching sensitive topics 7) Number of reports produced on the implementation of the Journalists’ Pact 8) Number of media outlets cooperating to produce supplements 9) Number of regions targeted by local level interventions 10) Local level peace building strategies and mechanisms implemented in at least three conflict-prone areas 11) Number of local leaders trained on mediation, conflict resolution and crisis management 12) Awareness raised among the population about truth, reconciliation and dealing with the past 13) Ex-fighters supported to play a positive role and convey messages of peace 14) Consultations held with different segments of the Lebanese society 15) Number of conflict assessments and maps produced

comment.narrative: 1) Rising tensions in schools hosting Syrian refugees 2) Absence of a collective memory of the civil war 3) High level of violence in Lebanese public and private schools 4) Absence of context-specific peace education content in the current high school curricula (including civics/history/geography education 5) Limited opportunities within the formal education sector to build a collective memory 6) Absence of new and modern ways of teaching history and sensitive topics 7) Need to implement master training for teacher trainers in use of Peace Building Toolbox 8) Limited initiatives involving young generation in oral history and the need to work on historical narrative 9)Lack of impartial and multifaceted reporting on issues affecting social cohesion in Lebanon and with communities hosting Syrian refugees in particular 10)The Journalists’ Pact for Strengthening Civil Peace signed but not yet implemented 11)Limited media monitoring on the type of and effects of reporting 12)Poor or biased coverage of strategic issues regarding the implementation of past agreements 13)Lack of channels for conveying positive messages through media 14) Absence of sustained peace building and dialogue mechanisms to mitigate the risks of potential violence at the local level 15) Limited awareness of the role that local actors such as municipalities and mukhtars can play in conflict prevention and mitigation. 16) Worsening tension between the Lebanese host communities and the Syrian refugees 17) Lack of a joint road map and a national strategy for truth and reconciliation 18) Limited field research on the perception of the causes, lived experience, and impact of the civil war in Lebanon, 19) Lack of consultation and coordination with state, non-state and other various segments of the Lebanese society on reconciliation 20) Absence awareness among the population about truth, reconciliation and dealing with the past through media 21) Absence of active ex-fighters wanting to promote pe
